column4: is there a command i can do to 1) search my home folder, 2)go through each filename and folder, 3)find any spaces and replace the spaces with underscores? I recently did a backup of windows files and some of them have spaces, despite every effort to enforce a no spaces policy.
yes, that's possible to do, but it's a bit involved.  There's no single command to do it.
that's one of the good things about unix though, really, lots of small/simple utilities which you can put together to do what you need...
currently im doing it manually through filezilla, so, anything might be better :)
hahaha.
my recommendation would be to use a shell script, really.
you might be able to do it w/ a single find command, but it'd be kind of tricky.
ever created a shell script before?
nope
alright..  ever written an actual *text* file, using nano or vi or something?
are all the files in one directory?
working on it, give me a few.
how would i go about making this work on all subdirectories? (recursively?)
you would need to split it up into directory and file components
you can do that by running 'dirname' on $line, that'll give you the directory
some of the directories have spaces too. is it pretty much the same proces but for dirs?
true...
is there some way of going to the last depth of directory and working back or does it not work that way?
here's my suggestion
create a set of directories which have some of these 'issues' and challenges
find ~ -name "* *" -type d, this limited my search and i found a few where i wanted instead of searching root which is / (or is that current directory?)
/ is 'root', current directory would be '.'
